monogr.title: The workes of Caius Crispus Salustius : contayning the Conspiracie of Cateline The Warre of Iugurth. V. bookes of historicall fragments. II orations to Cæsar for the institution of a co [m] monwealth and one against Cicero
monogr.author: Sallust

div.head: To the right Honorable the Lord Harbert of Castle Island, William Crosse wisheth the fulnesse of temporall and eternall happinesse.
div.p:
RIght Honourable, your gracious, though vndeserued favours, incourage me to present this piece of the Iugurthine war, to your most Noble hand, and able Iudgement. The Royall pen of Queene Elizabeth, hath beene formerly Verst in this Translation, but this being like to herselfe, and too good for the world, was neuer published. The subiect is high, copious, and full of variety: such are the sallies of the Authours
wit, such his expressions of language: both which are so well suited together, that without any Hyperbole or excesse of speech, I may boldly say, if there be any difference: Materiam superabat opus, the Worke-man-ship exceeds the matter. If this Worke may passe to publicke view, thrugh the fauour of your Patronage, the Labourer thinks his indeuours recompenced with a faire Haruest, and will for euer remaine

closer.signed: Your Honours deuoted Seruant, William Crosse.
